text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with gumbo that's right you know I
was in New Orleans recently and I
promised to do a few recipes inspired by
that trip and this is one of them a
gumbo of duck and dewy sausage and
shellfish alright so first step here I
have two duck legs that I'm going to
Brown in a little bit of vegetable oil
over medium heat this is of course going
to give the duck some color and flavor
but it's mostly gonna render the fat
which we're going to use to make the
famous roux which is the base of my
gumbo so I did about 10 minutes on the
skin side which is where most of the fat
is and maybe I don't know three or four
minutes on that meat side okay at this
point I'm going to remove the duck legs
to plate and reserve leaving all the fat
in the pan
I'm going to add a cup of flour stir
that in and then I have to decide if I
need more oil which you probably will
vegetable oil you want to add enough oil
to get a very smooth kind of thin
mixture okay I don't want to dry crumbly
Roux I want something that looks well
like that because we're going to cook
this a long time I'm going to turn the
heat down to medium-low I'm going to
switch to a wooden spoon and I'm just
going to keep cooking and cooking and
cooking this and it's going to go from
white to tan to light brown to like a
nutty brown - I don't really know any
other colors of brown it's going to get
deeper and darker and it's almost going
to get to like a brick red color is that
pretty which by the way that brick red
color is where the term a roux comes
from or so I've been told so this took
me believe it or not about 40 minutes
the deeper the color the deeper and
richer the flavor but also the less it
will thicken your gumbo so because of
that one trick I like to do when my roux
is done I'll throw in another couple
tablespoons of flour and only cook that
for like two minutes so I have a little
bit of flour that's not browned which
will help thicken this a little more
okay
so once that addition of flour has
cooked a couple minutes we're going to
finish this by slowly whisking in our
cold stock or broth I'm using
chicken I got about six cups by the way
all the measurements as usual will be on
food wishes comm basically the heat
still on medium low I'm simply going to
whisk in about a cup at a time because
it's a cold stock and a hot Roux it's
going to mix in there beautifully with
no lumps so pour some in whisk it up
pour some in whisk it up until all six
cups have been incorporated then just
turn it off and set it aside and then
we're on to the other gumbo ingredients
which for me and Dewey sausage I'm going
to brown that over medium heat in a deep
Dutch oven as soon as it looks like that
I'm going to throw in my Holy Trinity
that's right onions peppers celery I'm
using a couple different kinds of
peppers serrano for some heat and some
pasilla those are those dark green again
all the ingredients will be on food
wishes I'm going to stir that into my
browned and Dewey I'm going to add a
pinch of salt and I'm gonna sweat that
again on medium heat for about ten
minutes until the onions kind of start
to turn translucent and for those of you
that don't know and do is a smoky spicy
pork sausage and it's just absolutely
perfect for this all right so once those
vegetables have cooked with the sausage
for about ten minutes and they look like
that I'm going to throw in some dry
thyme a bay leaf some cayenne and a
little bit of black pepper give that a
stir and then a very controversial
ingredients I'm gonna throw in a little
bit of diced tomato okay so this is a
huge point of contention some say always
some say never some say sometimes now
the only thing that most people agree on
with a gumbo is it was originally
developed to use which you had around so
by that philosophy Tomatoes if you have
them around which I did totally
appropriate so I added them so I stirred
in the tomatoes and then I added this a
smoked ham hock look at that big old
bone how is it not going to be good with
a big old bone like that in it I'm going
to go ahead and I'm going to pour in our
stock room mixture along with a little
bit of water because this is going to
cook so long we need a good amount of
liquid to start here at that point we
can add our duck legs back in and we
want to bring this up to a simmer so you
can turn the heat up when it comes to a
very gentle simmer I want you to turn it
down
to low cover it almost leave it cracked
I don't want to cover completely alright
I want a little bit of steam to escape
cover it leave a little bit of an
opening and let that simmer for four or
five hours
very gently give it a stir every once in
a while and as it simmers I want you to
skim any fat that comes to the top so we
have a lot of fat in that room we got a
lot of fat in our ham hock those duck
legs have fat in it and you're going to
see I got almost a cup of fat off the
top here so I'll look like we had a lot
of oil involved in this a lot does float
up to the surface and you get rid of it
so now we're talking about like you know
diet food practically so like I said
simmer that for about four hours until
your meat is completely tender that pork
will start to fall off that hock meat on
the duck legs will just be fork tender
at that point you're going to remove the
meat tool Bowl what we're going to do is
we're going to pick that meat off the
bone and put it back in the gumbo next
step I'm gonna add some okra but I'm not
going to use fresh okra I'm not going to
use frozen okra I'm going to use pickled
okra so I like the appearance I like the
taste of okra I don't necessarily love
the texture it gives the gumbo which
some people kind of refer to as slimy so
by cutting up some pickled okra rinsing
it and adding that you get a little bit
of acidity to balance this richness but
you don't necessarily get any major
textural issues so that's just my little
alternative method with the okra and I
can't confirm or deny I did it this way
because my store was out of frozen okra
all right so I'm gonna stir the okra in
and like I said I want to simmer that
for about 45 minutes in the meantime my
meat will have cooled I can go ahead and
pick all the meat off the bones I'm
going to add any pork and duck back to
the gumbo so give that a stir and again
we're going to let that simmer we want
that okra to cook about 45 minutes just
to make sure everything is doing its
part
okay gumbo is a team effort alright last
step I'm going to turn up the heat so it
starts boiling a little quicker and I'm
going to add my seafood I have beautiful

by using some kind of imported Southeast

some langostino tails which are my

crayfish or
crawdads how come there's no crate ads
anyway I'm going to stir that in that's
only going to take like three minutes to
cook through and then you're ready to
eat
last thing optional a little bit of

course you tasted this for seasoning
salt pepper spice once I stir that in
this is ready to serve I'm going to put
it in a big little bowl I'm going to put

some extra green onion maybe some

anyway there you go there's a million

all you Cajuns relax
especially you raging Cajuns so it's
